text:
As students get ready to start classes around the world, we're making our most advanced AI tools available to college students in the US, Japan, Indonesia, South Korea, and Brazil, for free through a 12-month Google AI Pro plan. We‚Äôre also funding $1 billion to support AI education and job training programs, including making our Grow with Google AI and career training free for every college student in America. 

Having regular access to computers in grad school changed my life, and led me on the path to Google. It‚Äôs my hope that bringing the best AI tools to today‚Äôs college students will open up new worlds for them, too. Deadline for students to apply for the AI Pro Plan offer is October 6th! More details in my blog post here:
https://lnkd.in/e9WjqKNC

A milestone for the use of AI in cybersecurity: Our security AI agent, Big Sleep, proactively found a major vulnerability in SQLite, a popular open-source library, that attackers were about to exploit. Our teams were able to cut off the threat before it impacted users. We believe this is a first for AI in cybersecurity, which could go a long way in stopping threats before they become widespread. More from our recent AI security

Fusion energy could help meet the world‚Äôs energy needs for generations to come. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre making a long-term bet to help prove and scale it, in the same way we‚Äôre doing for nuclear energy from small modular reactors and geothermal. 

To start, we‚Äôre making the largest direct corporate purchase of fusion power from Commonwealth Fusion Systems‚Äôs future plant. We‚Äôre also investing to help them build on promising breakthroughs. For example, their high-temperature superconductor magnets can be used by smaller machines, which are significantly cheaper and faster to build.

The path to commercialization won‚Äôt be easy, but we think the upsides could be transformative.

Probably one of the longest interviews I‚Äôve ever done üòÖ, but I really enjoyed my wide-ranging conversation with Lex Fridman and going deep on so many areas of technology progress. Plus Lex tries out our new XR glasses and Google Beam!

Hello from Google I/O! Just got off the stage here at Shoreline Amphitheatre in Mountain View, where we shared how decades of AI research is becoming reality for people around the world. A few of the things we announced:

- AI Mode in Search is now rolling out to everyone in the US, expanding on what AI Overviews can do.

- An improved Gemini 2.5 Flash and an enhanced Deep Think mode coming to Gemini 2.5 Pro.

- Veo 3 is state of the art, and with a new filmmaking tool Flow, we‚Äôre combining the best of Veo, Imagen and Gemini.

- A new agent mode in the Gemini app can help you get more done across the web.

- New real-time translation is coming to Google Meet, and we introduced an AI-first video platform for 3D experiences called Google Beam. 

- Personalized smart replies are coming to Gmail 

- A glimpse into the future with XR glasses

We also shared some of the incredible momentum we‚Äôre seeing with our models, the rapid adoption of AI across our products, and much more.

It was great to sit down with David Friedberg from the All-In team for a wide-ranging conversation. Fun to reminisce and look ahead‚Ä¶ from how we see a big opportunity with Search, the investments we‚Äôre making in our world-class infrastructure and TPUs, and how we‚Äôre leaning into these moments of massive innovation.

Thanks again to David for the time.

It‚Äôs been a strong start to 2025 ‚Äî and we‚Äôre only just getting started üöÄ
Across Google and Alphabet, Q1 saw great momentum in our products, our platforms, and the impact we‚Äôre having around the world.

A few highlights:

üîπ Gemini 2.5, our most intelligent model yet, is leading the industry and sets a strong foundation for our future innovation.
üîπ AI Overviews in Search are now used by over 1.5 billion people each month, and we‚Äôre excited about the early reaction to AI Mode in Search, lots more to come.
üîπ Subscriptions surpassed 270 million, led by YouTube and Google One.
üîπ Gemini is now available in all 15 Google products that have over half a billion users ‚Äî and it‚Äôs redefining what AI-first smartphones can do, including our latest Pixel 9a.
üîπ At Google Cloud Next, we launched Ironwood, our most powerful TPU to date, and became the first to offer NVIDIA‚Äôs next-gen Blackwell GPUs. We‚Äôre also rolling out new tools for building and orchestrating multi-agent AI systems.
üîπ YouTube celebrated its 20th birthday ‚Äî still #1 in U.S. streaming on TVs, and now with 125M+ Music & Premium subscribers and over a billion podcast users.
üîπWaymo is now serving 250,000+ paid rides a week, and started operation in Silicon Valley. Miami and DC coming next year!

This work is only possible thanks to the incredible teams across Alphabet ‚Äî thank you. With I/O, Brandcast, and Google Marketing Live just around the corner ‚Äî there‚Äôs so much more to come in Q2!

Hello, Las Vegas! Had a great time this morning on stage at #GoogleCloudNext where we unveiled our 7th-gen TPU, Ironwood, purpose-built for inference and with massive gains (3,600x performance and 29x better energy efficiency our first Cloud TPU. It‚Äôs coming later this year!)

We also announced that Cloud Wide Area Network, based on Google‚Äôs own global-scale network, is coming soon too. And we launched new features in Google Agentspace that make it easier to create and adopt agents, as well as Gemini 2.5 Flash, our low-latency and most cost-efficient model with ‚Äúthinking‚Äù built-in - coming soon in AI Studio, Vertex + Gemini app. 

AI enables powerful new capabilities, but the most exciting part is what people do with them. 

I saw an incredible example of that last night at Las Vegas Sphere, where we gave a sneak peek into how AI is helping to enrich the Wizard of Oz experience coming to the Sphere later this year. Google‚Äôs been working with visual effects artists around the world and our AI models to effectively bring the film‚Äôs original characters to a whole new life for 2025. We‚Äôre a company full of engineers, problem solvers‚Ä¶and movie buffs. So the prospect of introducing a classic American film to an entirely new generation was an exciting one!

Great to see Alphabet / Google at the top of this list. I've always thought the best 'perk' of the company is my fellow Googlers - brilliant, innovative, and entirely focused on making helpful things for our users and customers. Just a few weeks shy of my 21st (!) Googleversary and still feeling lucky.

It‚Äôs not every day we have a launch that actually involves a rocket.  After a successful flight over the weekend, the first FireSat satellite is now in orbit! üõ∞Ô∏è It‚Äôs the first of about 50 that we‚Äôre launching over the coming few years to help track and detect wildfires, using AI. 

FireSat was designed to give us better tools to track and detect fires. Using advanced sensors and high resolution, it can detect a fire as small as 5x5 meters, which wasn't possible before. It updates every 20 minutes, comparing fresh imagery against historical data and factoring in local conditions like infrastructure and weather. Then it beams updates to emergency teams on the ground so they can react in real time. 

FireSat builds on our work using AI to map the boundaries of large wildfires and get people accurate information in 27 countries (including during the LA fires earlier this year.) In the next few weeks we‚Äôll start testing, and the system will be fully operational over the next few years.

This is a huge effort with many partners including Muon Space, Earth Fire Alliance, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. Here‚Äôs a photo of the satellite on the launch pad last Friday, waiting for a ride:

Bonjour! I‚Äôm in Paris this week for the AI Action Summit, co-chaired by French President Emmanuel Macron and India‚Äôs Prime Minister Narendra Modi. It‚Äôs been amazing to see so many leaders across tech, business and government gathered in one place to talk about the opportunity with AI. 

As I said in my remarks at the Grand Palais, that opportunity is as big as it gets. There are so many examples of how AI is already transforming science, business, and how we live, learn and work. It‚Äôs why we at Google are so energized about this moment, and the most exciting use cases are still to come. (You can read my full remarks here: https://goo.gle/3CMn2qw). 

After the summit, I had the chance to visit the Institut Curie, which is using Google‚Äôs AI tools to better predict the progression of women‚Äôs cancers and develop more effective treatments. A year ago I visited the Institut for the first time to start these conversations. So much progress has been made in just a year! I got to look at some of the tissue samples that can now be processed at a massive scale, thanks to AI. It‚Äôs an incredible reminder of the potential of this technology to save lives.

Just wrapped my Q4 + FY earnings remarks. It was another strong quarter, capping off a great year at the company. We‚Äôre in a great rhythm ‚Äì building, testing and launching products faster than ever before. Our leadership in AI innovation and our unique full-stack approach is translating into product usage, revenue growth and results.

We saw dramatic progress in AI, including with our latest model Gemini 2.0. Over 4.4 million developers are now building with Gemini, our Gemini app is now on iOS and doing really well there, and we‚Äôre seeing great feedback on our latest thinking models. Our Deep Research agentic research assistant, launched in December, is now on all Android devices, really recommend giving it a try if you haven‚Äôt yet.

In Search, AI Overviews are now available in more than 100 countries, and continue to drive higher satisfaction and increased Search usage. Circle to Search is going great, too. 2025 is going to be a big year for search innovation.

Our Cloud and YouTube businesses finished the year strong, reaching a combined annual run rate of $110 billion. Waymo safely served more than 4 million passenger trips and is expanding to more cities, including Tokyo. 

A big thank you to all Googlers around the world for this progress, I‚Äôm excited for the year ahead.

Today we‚Äôre celebrating 1 million graduates of our Grow With Google Career Certificates. This is a special milestone for so many reasons, but most of all because it represents 1 million stories of people looking to pursue new opportunities and careers. People like James Bingham, a former staff sergeant in the US AirForce who landed a civilian job as an IT Project Manager with help from our Project Management certificate.That list also includes Natalie Burns, who I met in 2019. Natalie earned her Google IT Support certificate while attending community college in Texas. She got a job in cybersecurity and a significant pay increase. In total, more than 70% of graduates report a positive career outcome within 6 months of completing our certificates, be it a job change, a promotion, or a raise. 

It also represents a greater impact than we could have imagined when we launched our first certificate in IT on Coursera in 2018. At the time, we were noticing a gap between the number of unfilled positions in tech and the number of people who were hungry to fill those roles, yet didn‚Äôt have access to the necessary training. Our Career Certificates could help fill that gap, providing pathways to learning that didn‚Äôt require a previous degree.

More than six years later, we now offer several certificates in fields like data analytics, cybersecurity, UX design and more. It‚Äôs a model we think can be replicated and expanded to even more opportunities, which will be especially important as we transition the economy for the AI era.

One of the most profound ways AI will improve lives is by accelerating science and discovery. This week, Demis Hassabis, James Manyika, and other Google leaders hosted our first-ever AI for Science Forum to share some of our recent progress here - from our work on the Nobel Prize-winning AlphaFold, which cracked the ‚Äúgrand challenge‚Äù of protein structure prediction, to connectomics research that helped map a tiny portion of the human brain in unprecedented detail to support health research, and much more.

AI research breakthroughs are leading to real-world benefits, for example: improvements to our AI model can now accurately predict floods days earlier than previously possible, while our high-resolution satellite imagery can help firefighters spot wildfires before they grow out of control. 

To help others expand their impact, we're launching a $20 million fund to support academic and nonprofit organizations who are using AI to advance scientific breakthroughs. This is on top of the more than $200 million Google.org has provided for this work over the last five years. 

AI has massive potential to benefit the world, so we are acting boldly to apply it as quickly as we can, while doing so responsibly. A huge thank you to all of the organizations and researchers around the world driving this important work forward.

Just got off our Q3 earnings call. TL;DR: It was a great quarter. 

Now for the longer version: Over the last quarter, the momentum across the company continued to be extraordinary. Our commitment to innovation, and the long term focus and investment in AI, are driving success for the company and for our customers.

We are uniquely positioned to lead in the era of AI because of our differentiated full stack approach to innovation ‚Äî from our robust AI infrastructure, to our world class research teams who do deep technical research and build the latest AI models (including Gemini), to the global reach of our products and platforms that touch billions of people and customers around the world. 

Also want to call out that AI Overviews in Search will now reach 1B users globally across 100+ countries. We're seeing strong engagement, which is increasing overall search usage and user satisfaction. People are asking longer and more complex questions, and exploring a wider range of websites.

Plus, I was excited to share the great momentum by our teams at YouTube, Cloud, Platforms & Devices and Waymo (took my parents for a Waymo ride a few weeks ago when we were out and about in San Francisco ‚Äî they loved it!).

What a special week for AI ‚Ä¶ huge congrats to Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for the Nobel in Chemistry recognizing the AlphaFold 2 breakthrough. It‚Äôs been incredible to witness their Nobel Prize-winning work in the making ‚Äî knew from the early days that AlphaFold would have a huge impact in the world. And congratulations to Geoff Hinton for the Nobel in Physics ‚Äî so well deserved!

This week my travels took me back to Japan, where we opened our first international office in 2001. I always find Japan to be a place willing to adopt new technologies, and I could clearly see the big shift in the progress happening with AI, from the cutting edge research to the vibrant startup AI ecosystem to an incredible developer community.

The main reason for my visit was for a gathering of Google's top customers in Japan, including government and business leaders. While there, I watched rakugo, a traditional form of Japanese comedy, for the first time. Bunshi Katsura, a legendary rakugo artist, showed me how he used Gemini to enhance his set. It was incredibly moving to see such an honored tradition transformed by AI, while keeping humanity at the heart.

I also spent time with students and developers. I met with researchers from the Matsuo Lab at the University of Tokyo to hear more about how they are tackling hard challenges in AI, and middle school students taking part in Mind the Gap, our grassroots program designed to address the underrepresentation of women in technology. And I dropped by to say thank you to our Japanese and South Korean developer community and help unveil our Japanese-tuned Gemma 2 2B.

Of course, my favorite part of traveling is seeing Googlers around the world. I joined Googlers at our Tokyo office and around the region to talk about the deep investments happening there and the incredible opportunities ahead. We also welcomed a very special celebrity guest to the Tokyo office ‚Äî Pikachu ‚Äî to celebrate an amazing milestone for Pok√©mon Kids TV Japan (in addition to the millions of subscribers on their global channel). Couldn‚Äôt resist a quick selfie with such a big superstar :)

Yesterday I was in Pittsburgh, which is a really special place for me - one of the first cities I visited in the US and where we announced our Grow with Google economic opportunity initiative in 2017. I spent the day with the next generation of technologists, from high schoolers who are starting to explore STEM, to college students embarking on their computer science and technology careers.

First stop - the Pittsburgh Google office where I spoke with students who shared STEM projects that they‚Äôre working on, and teachers who are exploring how to bring AI into their classrooms. As part of that, we announced a $25 million fund from Google.org for organizations that are helping educators and students across the US build their AI skills.

Over at Carnegie Mellon University, students showed me around the Robotics Institute and the Mission Control Lab, where I got to see a model of Iris, the smallest rover ever to go to space (very cool). While there, I gave a talk about how AI is accelerating scientific discovery and chatted with President Farnam Jahanian and over 2,000 students. Super inspiring and can't wait to come back!
